com.larphoid.lanudpcomm

Class LanUDPComm

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.larphoid.lanudpcomm.LanUDPComm
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ClientEventHandler, ClientInviteHandler, ClientsEventHandler

    public class LanUDPComm
extends java.lang.Object
implements ClientsEventHandler, ClientInviteHandler, ClientEventHandler
    © 2013 Larphoid Apps.
    Since:
    05-09-2013
    Author:
    Larphoid Apps

    - NOTICE -

    The first byte value in the byte[] parameter of DatagramPacket.getData() or onClientsEvent(byte[], DatagramPacket) when sending sendClientPacket() / sendClientPacket(String) is reserved for internal use by LanUDPComm.
    These byte values are: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8, which mean NO, YES, STRING_SPLIT_SEPARATOR, HI, BYE, CLIENT_INVITE, BUSY, KEEP_ALIVE, and CLIENT_EVENT respectively.
    If you need further communication commands, store them in the next byte(s) when using sendClientPacket() or in the String when using sendClientPacket(String).

      • waitForInviteResponse

        public ProgressDialog waitForInviteResponse
        Use this whenever you want to show a waiting dialog. Simply call yourLanUDPCommInstance.waitForInviteResponse.show() and yourLanUDPCommInstance.waitForInviteResponse.dismiss() to hide it again.

    • Constructor Detail

      • LanUDPComm

        public LanUDPComm(Activity pActivity,
          DialogInterface.OnDismissListener pDialogDismissListener,
          int pDiscoveryPort,
          int pClientCommunicationPort,
          int pMaxClientEventPacketSize,
          ClientInviteHandler pClientInterface,
          ClientEventHandler pClientEventHandler,
          java.lang.String pMyDisplayName,
          boolean pNeedAliveConnection)
        Parameters:
        pActivity - Activity that LanUDPComm operates on, for instance to show dialogs on the application's UI thread.
        pDialogDismissListener - Callback interface that will be called when any of the dialogs are dismissed. Can be null if not needed.
        pDiscoveryPort - The discovery port number. If <= 0, it will be set to LanCommander's internal default.
        pClientCommunicationPort - The communications port for direct client to client communication. If <= 0, defaults to LanCommander's internal default.
        pMaxClientEventPacketSize - The maximun packet size for sending DatagramPackets to a connected client. If <= 0 defaults to 1024.
        pClientInterface - Required. A ClientInviteHandler interface to receive notifications about events like invite, inivite response and the start of a connection. If not needed, simply do nothing in the methods.
        pClientEventHandler - Required. A ClientEventHandler interface to receive client to client communication. If not needed, simply do nothing in the methods.
        pMyDisplayName - The name of the user. Can be null if not needed. In that case, this client's ip is used instead.
        pNeedAliveConnection - Whether or not a connection needs to be 'alive'.
        If true, LanUDPComm will send invite requests, show a waiting dialog until the client responds, and will inform back about accept/decline.
        If false, there is no checking if the client responds or not, and data can always be send to the last inviteClientForConnection(int, java.lang.String, java.lang.String[]) client.

    • Method Detail

      • onInviteAccept

        public java.lang.String[] onInviteAccept()
        Description copied from interface: ClientInviteHandler
        Called when this client accepts an invite request, providing a way to send application specific data along with the accept response.
        Specified by:
        onInviteAccept in interface ClientInviteHandler
        Returns:
        An array of Strings as data to send along with the invite response back to the inviting client. May be null if not needed.

      • onStartConnection

        public void onStartConnection(java.lang.String[] data,
                     int offset,
                     java.net.DatagramPacket pack)
        Description copied from interface: ClientInviteHandler
        Called at the target side, when the target has accepted an invite, to signal the start of the connection.
        If needAliveConnection is false, this will always get called without the target having to accept, so that the application can keep track of client status.
        Specified by:
        onStartConnection in interface ClientInviteHandler
        Parameters:
        data - The String array with your application specific data that was specified in ClientInviteHandler.onInviteAccept().
        offset - The offset into the Sting array where your application specific data starts.
        pack - This is supplied for convenience reasons. It allows the application to access additional information stored in the DatagramPacket about a connection, such as DatagramPacket.getAddress().

      • onClientAccepted

        public void onClientAccepted(java.lang.String[] data,
                    int offset,
                    java.net.DatagramPacket pack)
        Description copied from interface: ClientInviteHandler
        Called at the inviting client side, when the target has accepted an invite, to signal the start of the connection.
        If needAliveConnection is false, this will always get called if the target's last inviteClientForConnection(int, String, String[]) ip equals the inviting client's ip, so that the application can keep track of client status.
        Specified by:
        onClientAccepted in interface ClientInviteHandler
        Parameters:
        data - The String array with your application specific data that was specified in ClientInviteHandler.onInviteAccept().
        offset - The offset into the Sting array where your application specific data starts.
        pack - This is supplied for convenience reasons. It allows the application to access additional information stored in the DatagramPacket about a connection, such as DatagramPacket.getAddress().

      • onClientsEvent

        public void onClientsEvent(byte[] buffer,
                  java.net.DatagramPacket pack)
        Description copied from interface: ClientsEventHandler
        Fired when a client sends an invite or other events related to Discovery. Used internally by LanCommander only.
        Specified by:
        onClientsEvent in interface ClientsEventHandler

      • getTimeString

        public final java.lang.String getTimeString(long timestamp,
                             int style)
        Get a Time String from a timestamp in the form of System.currentTimeMillis() value.
        Parameters:
        timestamp - The long time value in the form of System.currentTimeMillis().
        style - One of TIMESTRING_SHORT, TIMESTRING_MEDIUM, TIMESTRING_LONG or TIMESTRING_FULL.
        See SimpleDateFormat for information on these constants.
        Returns:
        A time String that is formatted according to style parameter.

      • setClientsAdapter

        public void setClientsAdapter(BaseAdapter pAdapter)
        Calling this method will enable LanUDPComm to reflect changes in the list of clients back to your application.
        Parameters:
        pAdapter - The (custom) adapter, that has to be created by your application prior to calling this method.
        This can be a SimpleAdapter or any custom Adapter that you need for your application. If you are creating a SimpleAdapter, be sure to use FROM_CLIENTS as the String[] parameter in the Adapter's constructor, and use getClientsData() to get the data needed for the List<? extends Map<String, ?>> parameter.

      • getMessagesAdapter

        public BaseAdapter getMessagesAdapter(Context context,
                             int layoutResId,
                             int[] to)
        Calling this method will enable LanUDPComm to reflect changes in the list of messages back to your application.
        Parameters:
        context - The application context.
        layoutResId - The Layout resource id for a single ListView item.
        to - An int array, consisting of a single entry, that holds the id of a TextView within the Layout resource to display the client name.

      • inviteClientForConnection

        public void inviteClientForConnection(int index,
                             java.lang.String message,
                             java.lang.String[] extraData)
        Invites a client for a connection. After the target client has accepted the invite, all subsequent calls to sendClientPacket() and sendClientPacket(String) will target this client.
        Parameters:
        index - The index into the clientlist adapter, previously instantiated with setClientsAdapter(BaseAdapter).
        message - The message to display to the target. This String should contain one %s or %1$s, that will hold the name of the inviting client. If null, it will fallback on a default message String that is included in LanUDPComm.
        extraData - An array of Strings to send along with the invitation. This data will be received in onStartConnection(String[], int, DatagramPacket). May be null if not needed.

      • sendDiscoveryRequest

        public void sendDiscoveryRequest(java.lang.String pDisplayName)
        Send a discovery request, optionally wih a Display Name, making yourself known to other devices. If this client's display name changes during the life cycle of you application, you should use this method again, to let other clients know the new display name.
        Parameters:
        pDisplayName - the (new) Display Name to send along with the Discovery request. If null, it will send this client's IP address.

      • sendDiscoveryToAllIps

        public void sendDiscoveryToAllIps(java.lang.String pDisplayName)

      • sendDiscoveryByeBye

        public void sendDiscoveryByeBye()

      • GetClientEventBuffer

        public java.nio.ByteBuffer GetClientEventBuffer()
        Get the ByteBuffer to use for storing binary data. The first byte is set to CLIENTEVENT for internal usage, as stated in the - NOTICE - of LanUDPComm. If this byte is changed, the data will not be recognized at the recipient side, and as such will not be handled correctly: the ClientEventHandler.onClientEvent(byte[], int, int, DatagramPacket) will not get called.

        CAUTION: It is your own responsibility not to exceed the ByteBuffer limit (pMaxClientPacketSize you supplied when instantiating LanUDPComm), or your application will crash if you do not catch the exception.
        Returns:
        ByteBuffer

      • sendClientPacket

        public void sendClientPacket()
        This is used for sending binary data to a client.
        First call GetClientEventBuffer() to get a handle to an already created ByteBuffer with a maximum size of the pMaxClientPacketSize parameter that was supplied to the LanCommander constructor. With this ByteBuffer you can store your data in a simple way with existing methods such as ByteBuffer.putFloat(float) etcetera. When you are done storing the data, call this method to send the data.

        CAUTION: It is your own responsibility not to exceed the ByteBuffer limit (pMaxClientPacketSize you supplied when instantiating LanUDPComm), or your application will crash if you do not catch the exception.

      • sendClientPacket

        public void sendClientPacket(java.lang.String data)
        This is used for sending String data to a target.
        Parameters:
        data - The data to be send.

      • sendClientBye

        public void sendClientBye()
        Call this if you don't have a needAliveConnection and you want to let the target client know that you are ending the connection. This is usefull for example for chat-like applications, so that ClientEventHandler.onClientEndConnection(DatagramPacket) gets called and you can show client status on the receiving end.

      • stopConnection

        public boolean stopConnection()
        Call this if you have a needAliveConnection and you want to let the target know that you are ending the connection. If this is not needed for your application, then you do not have to call this.
        Returns:
        true if the connection was actually stopped, false if it was already stopped.

        Gets the InetAddress of the client at a specific position in the list.
        Parameters:
        position - The position in the clients list to return information about.

        The number of clients in the clients list.

      • onClientEvent

        public void onClientEvent(byte[] data,
                 int offset,
                 int dataLength,
                 java.net.DatagramPacket pack)
        Description copied from interface: ClientEventHandler
        Callback that receives data that was send either with sendClientPacket() or sendClientPacket(String) for a connection that was previously established with LanUDPComm#inviteClientForConnection(int, String[]).

        There are two methods to use for communication. One for 'fast' binary data, and one for simple String data. It is 'fast' because if there are a lot of events and you need to send data other than String data, it can be very slow if you first have to convert it into a String.
        Specified by:
        onClientEvent in interface ClientEventHandler
        Parameters:
        data - A byte array which holds your application specific data, to use for communication between the 2 clients. To simply convert to a String, use: new String(data, offset, dataLength - offset).
        offset - The offset of the data in the byte array. You can use ByteBuffer to wrap the byte array and ByteBuffer.position(offset) to advance the byte array to this position.
        dataLength - The length of the data that is stored in the byte[] array.
        pack - Included for convenience reasons. The DatagramPacket holds all the information about the data that was received.
        See Also:
        For information on how to use data communication, see {@link LanUDPComm#sendClientPacket()} and {@link LanUDPComm#sendClientPacket(String data)}.

      • onClientEndConnection

        public void onClientEndConnection(java.net.DatagramPacket pack)
        Description copied from interface: ClientEventHandler
        Called when a client ends the connection.
        This is usefull for example for games to end the game state, or for chat-like applications to keep track of client status. If not needed, simply do nothing in this callback method.
        If you want a dialog displayed to inform this client that the target has ended the connection, call yourLanUDPCommInstance.onClientEndConnection(DatagramPacket).
        Specified by:
        onClientEndConnection in interface ClientEventHandler

      • onClientNotResponding

        public void onClientNotResponding(java.net.DatagramPacket pack)
        Description copied from interface: ClientEventHandler
        Called (if you have a needAliveConnection when a client is not responding anymore (no longer sending 'keepalive' packets).
        This is usefull for example for games to end the game state. If not needed, simply do nothing in this callback method.
        If you want a dialog displayed to inform this client that the target is not responding anymore, call yourLanUDPCommInstance.onClientNotResponding(DatagramPacket).
        Specified by:
        onClientNotResponding in interface ClientEventHandler

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected()
        Returns:
        Returns whether this client is currently connected to a client. If needAliveConnection is false, this method will always return true because then a connection is not required to be able to send data to other clients.

      • cleanup

        public void cleanup()
        Use this when your application exits and you need to let other clients know that this client is no longer available. If this is not needed for your application, then you do not have to call this.
